Discharge Follow Up
ABDUL BURIDI - Within 2 weeks
AMIT DWIVEDI - Within 2 weeks
Kevin DUNBAR MATOS - Within 2 to 4 weeks
Out patient Hemodialysis at Davita W Broadway MWF. Arrive at 6.20 am with VAD Caregiver. Bring VAD binder with you. HD session starts at 0700 hrs. - 2022-01-21 06:20

HD MWF at DaVita W Broadway 1st session on 5/211, W Broadway MWF. Arrive at 6.20 am with VAD Caregiver. Bring VAD binder with you. HD session starts at 0700 hrs.
transportation has been pre-arranged for HD on MWF through Federated Transportation
Labs as needed per dialysis center, other labs per home health/VNA upon request from VAD office.
HH to do dressing changes to RIJ Tunnelled cath once a week and PRN VAD trained caregiver (via Maxim care) to attend each outpt HD session beginning this Friday 5/21

Code Status
Start: 2022-01-03 14:45:00 EDT, Full Code, Continuous Order

Mr Parker is a 50 year old male with PMHx of ICM, HFrEF (ICM-TTE-11/2020-EF-29%), CAD s/p MI and PCI to RCA around 2014, HTN, T2DM, COPD and OSA Admitted with Right arm/wrist pain, swelling and fever. HD MWF

Admitted with Right arm/wrist pain, swelling and fever, possibly acute exacerbation of gout, pain and swelling improved with Colchicine and one dose of prednisone.
BCx on admission 1/4 + staph epi, likely contaminant, received on Vanco, ID consulted, does not recommend to continue ABX.
Regarding AHF, VAD: volume hyper, typically HD MWF per nephrology, showed some kidney fxn recovery, off dialysis since 2022-01-03 per nephrology, discontinued tunnel catheter, and s/p and Right arm brachiocephalic fistula with Vascular on 2022-01-10. worsening Volume status and kidney fxn noted, started on bumex gtt on 2022-01-11 per nephrology, however, did not respond well to diuresis. s/p insertion of tunneled catheter in the right internal jugular vein on 5/14 with Vascular. Restarted HD on 5/15 daily until volume stable per nephrology. He will continue HD MW Fr as out pt. HD arranged as above.
BP/MAP within goal with initiation of Carvedilol, tolerating. Dr. Buridi OK to dc patient after HD.
He will follow up with Vascular in 2 weeks, AHF in 2-4 weeks and Nephrology as above.
During the course of his stay, the following issues were addressed:
1. Rt wrist/hand swelling
-hand consult-poss gout
improved with Colchicine
2. Positive blood Cx
BCx 1/4 + staph epi, likely contaminant
- Received Vanco x 2 doses, then d/c, no further Abx recommended per ID.
3. Chronic HFrEF with low cardiac output
-s/p insertion of HeartMate 3 left ventricular assist device, ligation of left atrial appendage 2021-10-24
ICM
ICD (St. Jude)
Stage D, NYHA Class III
Diuretics: Bumex 4 mg po bid, HD today
BB: Coreg 12.5 mg po bid
Hydralazine 150 mg Q8H, Isosorbide dinitrate 30mg TID
AC: ASA, Eliquis .
DLES: dressing changes daily with Medihoney.
4. CAD
- s/p PCI to RCA 2014
- LHC 3-2019: LM/LAD/LCX patent arteries and patent prox RCA stent
- Cont ASA/Statin and BB
5.AKI on CKD, stage IV
--Cr baseline 2-2.5
--Nephrology following.
--s/p TDC removal and Right arm brachiocephalic fistula with Vascular on 2022-01-10
--s/p insertion of tunneled catheter in the right internal jugular vein on 5/14 with Vascular.
--HD M W fr
6. DM
- Hgb A1c 7.6 on 2021-09-04
- cont current home regimen
Discharge plan has been discussed with patient, and he agrees to discharge at this time. Discharge instructions have been provided and patient verbalized his understanding. Discharge plan has been discussed with attending Dr. Dunbar Matos and patient is stable for discharge home at this time.
_

Mr Parker is a 50 year old male with PMHx of ICM, HFrEF (ICM-TTE-11/2020-EF-29%), CAD s/p MI and PCI to RCA around 2014, HTN, T2DM, COPD and OSA
#Rt wrist/hand swelling
-hand consult-poss gout Vs cellulitis
-CT shows Cellulitis changes of the right forearm/wrist region without abscess or soft tissue emphysema.
-Pain improving with Colchicine
# Positive blood Cx
BCx 1/4 + staph epi, likely contaminant
- Received Vanco x 2 doses, then d/c, no further Abx recommended per ID.
# Chronic HFrEF with low cardiac output
-s/p insertion of HeartMate 3 left ventricular assist device, ligation of left atrial appendage 2021-10-24
ICM
ICD (St. Jude)
Stage D, NYHA Class III
- Bedside TTE 2021-10-25: severely enlarged RV w/leftward bowing of interventricular septum
- TTE 2021-11-03: Technically difficult study. VAD speed 6000 RPM. Left ventricle is mildly dilated. LVEDd 5.8 cm. The LV ejection fraction is visually estimated at 20%. Severe global hypokinesis of the left ventricle. The left ventricular septum is midline. The left ventricular device inflow cannula is seen in the apex with normal flow. The right ventricle is mildly enlarged. Moderate global hypokinesis of the right ventricle. The aortic valve opens intermittently. No aortic valve regurgitation. Trace mitral regurgitation is present. IVC plethoric consistent with right atrial pressure of 10 mmHg.
- LVAD speed decreased to 5600 RPM 2021-10-25 following bedside TTE, increased to 6000 RPM 2021-10-26, parameters stable
Speed/LSL: 6000/5600
HF/ VAD education provided
Volume: hyper
- Inotrope: none. d/c milrinone on 2021-12-01. Does not appear to have volume improvement/significant benefit from resumption of milrinone, therefore d/c milrinone.
- Diuretics: Bumex 4 mg po bid, HD today
Off HD now
- GDMT: BB: Coreg 12.5 mg po bid
Hydralazine 100 mg Q8H, Isosorbide dinitrate 30mg TID
- AC: ASA, Eliquis . resumed today
# CAD
- s/p PCI to RCA 2014
- LHC 3-2019: LM/LAD/LCX patent arteries and patent prox RCA stent
- Cont ASA/Statin and BB
# AKI on CKD, stage IV
- Cr baseline 2-2.5
- TDC in OR with Vascular 2021-11-30,
- Nephrology following.
-noted good response/incr urine out put with diuretics now since volume is more stable
--last HD 2022-01-03, now holding HD per nephrology d/t recovered renal fxn
-s/p TDC removal and Right arm brachiocephalic fistula with Vascular on 2022-01-10
-s/p i nsertion of tunneled catheter in the right internal jugular vein on 5/14 with Vascular.
-Restarting HD today per nephrology.
# Persistent Afib
- Amio drip post-operatively now transitioned to Amio PO 200 mg BID
- AC as above
# Obesity, class II with comorbidities
- Encourage to work on weight loss through healthy eating and calorie reduction, increase activity, and maintain BMI when awake
# DM
- Hgb A1c 7.6 on 2021-09-04
- cont current home regimen
# Post-operative respiratory failure
- Extubated 2021-11-07
- Reintubated 2021-11-08 for airway protection
- Trach per Thoracic 2021-11-09, exchanged to 6XLT 2021-11-19
- Trach removed 2021-12-03,
-stable, on room air
# Lymph adenopathy
Surveillance neck CT recommended in approximately 3 months to reevaluate left lower neck/supraclavicular adenopathy of uncertain
etiology.

Admitted with Right arm/wrist pain, swelling and fever, possibly acute exacerbation of gout, pain and swelling improving with Colchicine and one dose of prednisone. BCx on admission 1/4 + staph epi, likely contaminant, received on Vanco, now stopped, ID consulted, does not recommend to continue ABX.
Regarding AHF, VAD: volume hyper, typically HD MWF per nephrology, showed some kidney fxn recovery, off dialysis since 2022-01-03 per nephrology, discontinued tunnel catheter, and s/p and Right arm brachiocephalic fistula with Vascular on 2022-01-10. worsening Volume status and kidney fxn noted, started on bumex gtt on 2022-01-11 per nephrology, however, did not respond well to diuresis. s/p i nsertion of tunneled catheter in the right internal jugular vein on 5/14 with Vascular. R estarting HD today per nephrology. Continue to monitor.
BP/ MAP within goal with initiation of Carvedilol, tolerating.

-s/p insertion of HeartMate 3 left ventricular assist device, ligation of left atrial appendage 2021-10-24
ICM
ICD (St. Jude)
Stage D, NYHA Class III

- TTE 2021-11-03: Technically difficult study. VAD speed 6000 RPM. Left ventricle is mildly dilated. LVEDd 5.8 cm. The LV ejection fraction is visually estimated at 20%. Severe global hypokinesis of the left ventricle. The left ventricular septum is midline. The left ventricular device inflow cannula is seen in the apex with normal flow. The right ventricle is mildly enlarged. Moderate global hypokinesis of the right ventricle. The aortic valve opens intermittently. No aortic valve regurgitation. Trace mitral regurgitation is present. IVC plethoric consistent with right atrial pressure of 10 mmHg.
- LVAD speed decreased to 5600 RPM 2021-10-25 following bedside TTE, increased to 6000 RPM 2021-10-26, parameters stable

-s/p TDC removal and Right arm brachiocephalic fistula with Vascular on 2022-01-10, Resumed Eliquis 5/11.

A/P:
Admitted with Right arm/wrist pain, swelling and fever, possibly acute exacerbation of gout, pain and swelling improving with Colchicine and one dose of prednisone. BCx on admission 1/4 + staph epi, likely contaminant, received on Vanco, now stopped, ID consulted, does not recommend to continue ABX.
Regarding AHF, VAD: volume hyper, typically HD MWF per nephrology, now shows some kidney fxn recovery, off dialysis since 2022-01-03. per nephrology, discontinued tunnel catheter, however patient has underlying diabetic nephropathy with a stage IV kidney disease will need AV fistula placed. vascular consulted. s/p TDC removal and Right arm brachiocephalic fistula with Vascular on 2022-01-10. Volume status continues to be worsening with slightly worsening Cr, started on bumex gtt on 2022-01-11 per nephrology, will differ further adjustment of diuretics or HD to Nephrology. Cr trending up, suboptimal diuresis. It appears that pt may need to have HD restarted if Cr not improving.
Will continue to monitor volume status, kidney Fxn and BP. Long discussion with pt regarding importance of fluid restriction to 1800 ml/24 hrs and monitoring output.
5/13--BP/ MAP within goal with initiation of Carvedilol, tolerating.
5/14--scheduled for tunnel HD cath placement 215pm today, neph to decide dialysis run with pt, Eliquis on hold for OR today
ATTESTATION:
Patient seen/evaluated and I agree with above. NO new issues. Tolerating HD. D/C to home when OK from Nephrology standpoint.

BCx on admission 1/4 + staph epi, likely contaminant, received on Vanco, now stopped, ID consulted, does not recommend to continue ABX.
Regarding AHF, VAD: volume hyper, typically HD MWF per nephrology, now shows some kidney fxn recovery, off dialysis since 2022-01-03. per nephrology, discontinued tunnel catheter, however patient has underlying diabetic nephropathy with a stage IV kidney disease will need AV fistula placed. vascular consulted. s/p TDC removal and Right arm brachiocephalic fistula with Vascular on 2022-01-10. Volume status continues to be worsening with slightly worsening Cr, started on bumex gtt on 2022-01-11 per nephrology, will differ further adjustment of diuretics or HD to Nephrology. Cr trending up, suboptimal diuresis. It appears that pt may need to have HD restarted if Cr not improving.
Will continue to monitor volume status, kidney Fxn and BP. Long discussion with pt regarding importance of fluid restriction to 1800 ml/24 hrs and monitoring output.
BP/ MAP within goal with initiation of Carvedilol, tolerating.

General: No acute distress noted
Neurologic: Awake, Alert, and Oriented x3. Following all commands
Lungs: Clear to auscultation, non-labored respiration, on RA
Heart: NSR on monitor, no ectopy noted, No JVD noted. LVAD hum auscultated. +2 Edema BLE noted
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender to palpation, non-distended, active bowel sounds

Assessment/Plan:
- DLES is healing well, continue with dressing changes daily using driveline exit site kit and paper tape. Instructed patient on proper cleansing/scrubbing techniques including exposing portion of driveline just below the skin and removing any biofilm with each dressing change. May rotate orientation of driveline as it exits the skin and adjust orientation of the dressing to prevent skin damage from the adhesive dressing being placed on same area of skin with each dressing change. Instructed patient to call with any new erythema, drainage, swelling, tenderness, warmth, fever, chills.
- Patient is not cleared for shower bag at this time. Will follow up at next visit and will likely be cleared to begin showering at that time if all incisions healed.
- Discussed with patient that if performing any activities that cause perspiration, best practice is to change DLES dressing after activity to avoid allowing an perspiration or moisture to sit at DLES for extended periods of time.
- Sternum stable to deep manual palpation. Now 11 weeks post implant (implant date 2/24). OK to begin lifting > 10lbs as tolerated but has been instructed to notify CV Surgery with any increased pain, clicking/popping. Will d/w VAD Coordinator, will need referral to cardiac rehab for ongoing rehabilitation once home health able to be dc'd. Encouraged patient to exercise daily.
- Remains on ASA 325mg daily, Eliquis on hold due to melena post-operatively, if labs stable per home health next week will consider resuming Eliquis.
- VAD parameters: reviewed and stable, no adjustments were made today.
- VS: reviewed. Vital signs stable
- Labs: reviewed and stable. Renal function still decreased. Has been getting HD per Renal recommendation, however renal function showing signed of improvement. HD on hold at this time per Renal recommendations. However patient appears to be increasing in fluid volume and Creat increased. S/P RUA fistula per vascular 2022-01-10.
- Medication: Amio 200 daily, Norvasc 10 Daily, Eliquis 5 BID, ASA 325 daily, Statin, Carvedilol 12.5mg BID,. Hydralazine 150 Q8H, Isosorbide 30 TID.

Mr Parker is a 50 year old male with PMHx of ICM, HFrEF (ICM-TTE-11/2020-EF-29%), CAD s/p MI and PCI to RCA around 2014, HTN, T2DM, COPD and OSA
#Rt wrist/hand swelling
-hand consult-poss gout Vs cellulitis
-CT shows Cellulitis changes of the right forearm/wrist region without abscess or soft tissue emphysema.
-Pain improving with Colchicine
# Positive blood Cx
BCx 1/4 + staph epi, likely contaminant
- Received Vanco x 2 doses, then d/c, no further Abx recommended per ID.
# Chronic HFrEF with low cardiac output
-s/p insertion of HeartMate 3 left ventricular assist device, ligation of left atrial appendage 2021-10-24
ICM
ICD (St. Jude)
Stage D, NYHA Class III
- Bedside TTE 2021-10-25: severely enlarged RV w/leftward bowing of interventricular septum
- TTE 2021-11-03: Technically difficult study. VAD speed 6000 RPM. Left ventricle is mildly dilated. LVEDd 5.8 cm. The LV ejection fraction is visually estimated at 20%. Severe global hypokinesis of the left ventricle. The left ventricular septum is midline. The left ventricular device inflow cannula is seen in the apex with normal flow. The right ventricle is mildly enlarged. Moderate global hypokinesis of the right ventricle. The aortic valve opens intermittently. No aortic valve regurgitation. Trace mitral regurgitation is present. IVC plethoric consistent with right atrial pressure of 10 mmHg.
- LVAD speed decreased to 5600 RPM 2021-10-25 following bedside TTE, increased to 6000 RPM 2021-10-26, parameters stable
Speed/LSL: 6000/560
HF/ VAD education provided
Volume: hyper
- Inotrope: none. d/c milrinone on 2021-12-01. Does not appear to have volume improvement/significant benefit from resumption of milrinone, therefore d/c milrinone.
- Diuretics: will increase bumex 3 mg po tid. known for diuretic resistance, now responding.
Off HD now
- GDMT: BB: Coreg 12.5 mg po bid
Hydralazine 100 mg Q8H, Isosorbide dinitrate 30mg TID
- AC: ASA, Eliquis . will hold Eliquis from 5/8, plan for OR Monday
# CAD
- s/p PCI to RCA 2014
- LHC 3-2019: LM/LAD/LCX patent arteries and patent prox RCA stent
- Cont ASA/Statin and BB
# AKI on CKD, stage IV
- Cr baseline 2-2.5
- TDC in OR with Vascular 2021-11-30,
- Nephrology following.
-noted good response/incr urine out put with diuretics now since volume is more stable
--last HD 2022-01-03, now holding HD per nephrology d/t recovered renal fxn
-Nephrology recs removal of TDC, and new AVF, Vascular consulted, plans for AVF Monday
-will continue to follow
# Persistent Afib
- Amio drip post-operatively now transitioned to Amio PO 200 mg BID
- AC as above
# Obesity, class II with comorbidities
- Encourage to work on weight loss through healthy eating and calorie reduction, increase activity, and maintain BMI when awake
# DM
- Hgb A1c 7.6 on 2021-09-04
- cont current home regimen
# Post-operative respiratory failure
- Extubated 2021-11-07
- Reintubated 2021-11-08 for airway protection
- Trach per Thoracic 2021-11-09, exchanged to 6XLT 2021-11-19
- Trach removed 2021-12-03,
-stable, on room air
# Lymph adenopathy
Surveillance neck CT recommended in approximately 3 months to reevaluate left lower neck/supraclavicular adenopathy of uncertain
etiology.
A/P:
Admitted with Right arm/wrist pain, swelling and fever, possibly acute exacerbation of gout, pain and swelling improving with Colchicine and one dose of prednisone. BCx on admission 1/4 + staph epi, likely contaminant, received on Vanco, now stopped, ID consulted, does not recommend to continue ABX.
Regarding AHF, VAD: volume hyper, Cr stable, typically HD MWF per nephrology, now shows some kidney fxn recovery, off dialysis now with last one on 2022-01-03. per nephrology, pt may not need dialysis currently, recs to discontinue tunnel catheter, however patient has underlying diabetic nephropathy with a stage IV kidney disease will need AV fistula placed. Consulted vascular for possible removal of TDC and AVF, planed for OR Monday, pt agrees.
BP/ MAP within goal with initiation of Carvedilol, tolerating . Will continue to monitor volume status, kidney Fxn and BP. Long discussion with pt regarding importance of fluid restriction to 1800 ml/24 hrs and monitoring output. Weight is up, and slightly worsening LE edema, therefore increased bumex to 3 mg po tid.
Plan for fistula creation and removal of tunnel cath in OR Monday
ATTESTATION:
patient seen/evaluated and I agree with above. No issues overnight. Feels well. VAD/VSS. Tentatively planned for AV fistula tomorrow. Making urine - weight appears to be stable

Mr Parker is a 50 year old male with PMHx of ICM, HFrEF (ICM-TTE-11/2020-EF-29%), CAD s/p MI and PCI to RCA around 2014, HTN, T2DM, COPD and OSA
#Rt wrist/hand swelling
-hand consult-poss gout Vs cellulitis
-CT shows Cellulitis changes of the right forearm/wrist region without abscess or soft tissue emphysema.
-Pain improving with Colchicine
# Positive blood Cx
BCx 1/4 + staph epi, likely contaminant
- Received Vanco x 2 doses, then d/c, no further Abx recommended per ID.
# Chronic HFrEF with low cardiac output
-s/p insertion of HeartMate 3 left ventricular assist device, ligation of left atrial appendage 2021-10-24
ICM
ICD (St. Jude)
Stage D, NYHA Class III
- Bedside TTE 2021-10-25: severely enlarged RV w/leftward bowing of interventricular septum
- TTE 2021-11-03: Technically difficult study. VAD speed 6000 RPM. Left ventricle is mildly dilated. LVEDd 5.8 cm. The LV ejection fraction is visually estimated at 20%. Severe global hypokinesis of the left ventricle. The left ventricular septum is midline. The left ventricular device inflow cannula is seen in the apex with normal flow. The right ventricle is mildly enlarged. Moderate global hypokinesis of the right ventricle. The aortic valve opens intermittently. No aortic valve regurgitation. Trace mitral regurgitation is present. IVC plethoric consistent with right atrial pressure of 10 mmHg.
- LVAD speed decreased to 5600 RPM 2021-10-25 following bedside TTE, increased to 6000 RPM 2021-10-26, parameters stable
Speed/LSL: 6000/560
HF/ VAD education provided
Volume: hyper
- Inotrope: none. d/c milrinone on 2021-12-01. Does not appear to have volume improvement/significant benefit from resumption of milrinone, therefore d/c milrinone.
- Diuretics: will increase bumex 3 mg po tid. known for diuretic resistance, now responding.
Off HD now
- GDMT: BB: Coreg 12.5 mg po bid
Hydralazine 100 mg Q8H, Isosorbide dinitrate 30mg TID
- AC: ASA, Eliquis . will hold Eliquis from 5/8, plan for OR Monday
# CAD
- s/p PCI to RCA 2014
- LHC 3-2019: LM/LAD/LCX patent arteries and patent prox RCA stent
- Cont ASA/Statin and BB
# AKI on CKD, stage IV
- Cr baseline 2-2.5
- TDC in OR with Vascular 2021-11-30,
- Nephrology following.
-noted good response/incr urine out put with diuretics now since volume is more stable
--last HD 2022-01-03, now holding HD per nephrology d/t recovered renal fxn
-Nephrology recs removal of TDC, and new AVF, Vascular consulted, plans for AVF Monday
-will continue to follow
# Persistent Afib
- Amio drip post-operatively now transitioned to Amio PO 200 mg BID
- AC as above
# Obesity, class II with comorbidities
- Encourage to work on weight loss through healthy eating and calorie reduction, increase activity, and maintain BMI when awake
# DM
- Hgb A1c 7.6 on 2021-09-04
- cont current home regimen
# Post-operative respiratory failure
- Extubated 2021-11-07
- Reintubated 2021-11-08 for airway protection
- Trach per Thoracic 2021-11-09, exchanged to 6XLT 2021-11-19
- Trach removed 2021-12-03,
-stable, on room air
# Lymph adenopathy
Surveillance neck CT recommended in approximately 3 months to reevaluate left lower neck/supraclavicular adenopathy of uncertain
etiology.
A/P:
Admitted with Right arm/wrist pain, swelling and fever, possibly acute exacerbation of gout, pain and swelling improving with Colchicine and one dose of prednisone. BCx on admission 1/4 + staph epi, likely contaminant, received on Vanco, now stopped, ID consulted, does not recommend to continue ABX.
Regarding AHF, VAD: volume hyper, Cr stable, typically HD MWF per nephrology, now shows some kidney fxn recovery, off dialysis now with last one on 2022-01-03. per nephrology, pt may not need dialysis currently, recs to discontinue tunnel catheter, however patient has underlying diabetic nephropathy with a stage IV kidney disease will need AV fistula placed. Consulted vascular for possible removal of TDC and AVF, planed for OR Monday, pt agrees.
BP/ MAP within goal with initiation of Carvedilol, tolerating . Will continue to monitor volume status, kidney Fxn and BP. Long discussion with pt regarding importance of fluid restriction to 1800 ml/24 hrs and monitoring output. Weight is up, and slightly worsening LE edema, therefore increased bumex to 3 mg po tid.
Plan for fistula creation and removal of tunnel cath in OR Monday
ATTESTATION:
patient seen/evaluated and I agree with above. No acute issues overnight. ? accuracy of I/Os - patient records more UOP. Tentatively planned for AV fistula on Monday. No HD since Monday - weight slowly rising and persistent edema. Appreciate assistance from Nephrology.

- Received Vanco x 2 doses, then d/c, no further Abx recommended per ID.
# Chronic HFrEF with low cardiac output
-s/p insertion of HeartMate 3 left ventricular assist device, ligation of left atrial appendage 2021-10-24
ICM
ICD (St. Jude)
Stage D, NYHA Class III
- Bedside TTE 2021-10-25: severely enlarged RV w/leftward bowing of interventricular septum
- TTE 2021-11-03: Technically difficult study. VAD speed 6000 RPM. Left ventricle is mildly dilated. LVEDd 5.8 cm. The LV ejection fraction is visually estimated at 20%. Severe global hypokinesis of the left ventricle. The left ventricular septum is midline. The left ventricular device inflow cannula is seen in the apex with normal flow. The right ventricle is mildly enlarged. Moderate global hypokinesis of the right ventricle. The aortic valve opens intermittently. No aortic valve regurgitation. Trace mitral regurgitation is present. IVC plethoric consistent with right atrial pressure of 10 mmHg.
- LVAD speed decreased to 5600 RPM 2021-10-25 following bedside TTE, increased to 6000 RPM 2021-10-26, parameters stable

A/P:
Admitted with Right arm/wrist pain, swelling and fever, possibly acute exacerbation of gout, pain and swelling improving with Colchicine and one dose of prednisone. BCx on admission 1/4 + staph epi, likely contaminant, received on Vanco, now stopped, ID consulted, does not recommend to continue ABX.
Regarding AHF, VAD: volume hyper, Cr stable, typically HD MWF per nephrology, now shows some kidney fxn recovery, off dialysis now with last one on 2022-01-03. per nephrology, pt may not need dialysis currently, recs to discontinue tunnel catheter, however patient has underlying diabetic nephropathy with a stage IV kidney disease will need AV fistula placed. Consulted vascular for possible removal of TDC and AVF, planed for OR Monday, pt agrees.
BP/ MAP within goal with initiation of Carvedilol, tolerating . Will continue to monitor volume status, kidney Fxn and BP. Long discussion with pt regarding importance of fluid restriction to 1800 ml/24 hrs and monitoring output. Weight is up, and slightly worsening LE edema, therefore increased bumex to 3 mg po tid.
Patient seen and examined with attending Dr. C Dunbar Matos. The above assessment/ plans were outlined after discussing with attending. Shared decision making was utilized in constructing this documentation and determination of the assessment and plan.

Prior to his admission, he developed acute on chronic renal failure with generalized anasarca resistant to diuretics, was on a daily dialysis for several weeks via TDC. He is now off HD and Vascular has been consulted for TDC removal and AVF creation.
He is right handed. He has an LVAD. He is on Eliquis.

No soft tissue emphysema. No focal abscess collection. No displacedfracture. No focal osseous lesions. No dislocation. Vascular structures not wellevaluated for patency secondary to timing of the scan.Other findings: Mildly enlarged left supraclavicular lymph node approximately 1.7 x2.1 cm. There is some stranding aroundthe sternotomy suggesting recent surgery. Left ventricular assist device noted onthe scout radiograph. There is a right IJ approach central line continuing intothe superior vena cava. Gynecomastia.IMPRESSION:Cellulitis changes of the right forearm/wrist region without abscess or soft tissueemphysema.Other findings as discussed. item.paragraph: (CR Chest 1 Vw Portable) Reason For Exam: tunneled dialysis catheter placement;Line Placement

paragraph.content:
EXAMINATION: Portable 1-view chest radiograph
DATE: 2022-01-14 1:15 PM
ACCESSION: 01CR210022250
PROVIDED INDICATION: Dialysis catheter placement
COMPARISON: Chest radiograph dated 2022-01-03
TECHNIQUE: A single portable AP radiograph of the chest was obtained.
FINDINGS: The tip of a dual lumen right internal jugular central venous catheter
terminates at the cavoatrial junction. A left ventricular assist device and the leads
of a left-sided pacemaker device are in unchanged position. Lung volumes are low, with
similar elevation of the right hemidiaphragm. Linear right basilar and left midlung
zone opacities are consistent with subsegmental atelectasis. Prominence of the central
pulmonary vessels is likely accentuated by hypoinflation/technique. Cardiomediastinal
contours are unchanged. There are no new osseous findings.
IMPRESSION:
1. Unchanged position of a right internal jugular central venous catheter.
2. Persistent low lung volumes with subsegmental atelectasis at the right lung base
and left midlung zone.
3. Prominence of the central pulmonary vessels could relate to hypoinflation/technique
or may represent mild pulmonary edema.
Dictated by:Mohiuddin Hadi
Dictated DT/TM: 2022-01-14 3:55 PM
Signed by: Mohiuddin Hadi
Signed DT/TM: 2022-01-14 6:25 PM

item.paragraph: (CT UE RT W) Reason For Exam: Cellulitis

paragraph.content:
INDICATION: Shortness of breath. Right upper extremity pain for one week.
Cellulitis.
TECHNIQUE: Thin section axial images were obtained through the right upper
extremity with intravenous contrast, from the shoulder to the hand. Orthogonal
reconstructed images were obtained and reviewed. Isovue 370 100 mL was
administered intravenously.
Note that the field-of-view included the head, neck and portions of upper chest
although protocol is not optimized for evaluation of these regions. Additionally,
with regard to right upper extremity protocol is not optimized for single large
joint evaluation, with large field-of-view.
Automated mA/kV exposure control was utilized and patient examination was performed
in strict accordance with principles of ALARA.
RADIATION AMOUNT: 920.66 mGy-cm.
COMPARISON: XR forearm 2022-01-03.
FINDINGS:
Problem specific findings: Soft tissue edema of the right mid/distal forearm, wrist
and hand. No soft tissue emphysema. No focal abscess collection. No displaced
fracture. No focal osseous lesions. No dislocation. Vascular structures not well
evaluated for patency secondary to timing of the scan.
Other findings: Mildly enlarged left supraclavicular lymph node approximately 1.7 x
2.1 cm. Nearby mildly enlarged left lower neck level 3/4 lymph node. AICD
incompletely imaged. Densely calcified right paratracheal lymph node 2.4 x 2.9 cm.
Lung apices are clear. Status post sternotomy. There is some stranding around
the sternotomy suggesting recent surgery. Left ventricular assist device noted on
the scout radiograph. There is a right IJ approach central line continuing into
the superior vena cava. Gynecomastia.
IMPRESSION:
Cellulitis changes of the right forearm/wrist region without abscess or soft tissue
emphysema.
Other findings as discussed. Surveillance neck CT recommended in approximately 3
months to reevaluate left lower neck/supraclavicular adenopathy of uncertain
etiology.
Signed by Jason Romesburg, DO

***** Final *****
Dictated by: ROMESBURG, JASON, RAD-RAD
Dictated DT/TM: 2022-01-03 6:51 am
Interpreted and electronically signed by: ROMESBURG, JASON, RAD-RAD
Signed DT/TM: 2022-01-03 7:04 am

text.paragraph: No data available for this section
No data available for this section
No data available for this section

Heart Failure, Self Care
Heart failure is a serious condition. This document explains the things you need to do to take care of yourself after a heart failure diagnosis. You may be asked to change your diet, take certain medicines, and make other lifestyle changes in order to stay as healthy as possible. Your health care provider may also give you more specific instructions. If you have problems or questions, contact your health care provider.
What are the risks?
Having heart failure puts you at higher risk for certain problems. These problems can get worse if you do not take good care of yourself. Problems may include:
• Blood clotting problems. This may cause a stroke.
• Damage to the kidneys, liver, or lungs.
• Abnormal heart rhythms.
Supplies needed:
• Scale for monitoring weight.
• Blood pressure monitor.
• Notebook.
• Medicines.
How to care for yourself when you have heart failure
Medicines
Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider. Medicines reduce the workload of your heart, slow the progression of heart failure, and improve symptoms. Take your medicines every day.
• Do not stop taking your medicine unless your health care provider tells you to do so.
• Do not skip any dose of medicine.
• Refill your prescriptions before you run out of medicine.
Eating and drinking
• Eat heart-healthy foods. Talk with a dietitian to make an eating plan that is right for you.
◦ Choose foods that contain no trans fat and are low in saturated fat and cholesterol. Healthy choices include fresh or frozen fruits and vegetables, fish, lean meats, legumes, fat-free or low-fat dairy products, and whole-grain or high-fiber foods.
◦ Limit salt (sodium) if told by your health care provider. Sodium restriction may reduce symptoms of heart failure. Ask a dietitian to recommend heart-healthy seasonings.
◦ Use healthy cooking methods instead of frying. Healthy methods include roasting, grilling, broiling, baking, poaching, steaming, and stir-frying.
• Limit your fluid intake, if directed by your health care provider. Fluid restriction may reduce symptoms of heart failure.
Alcohol use
• Do not drink alcohol if:
◦ Your health care provider tells you not to drink.
◦ Your heart was damaged by alcohol, or you have severe heart failure.
◦ You are pregnant, may be pregnant, or are planning to become pregnant.
• If you drink alcohol:
◦ Limit how much you use to:
▪ 0–1 drink a day for women.
▪ 0–2 drinks a day for men.
◦ Be aware of how much alcohol is in your drink. In the U.S., one drink equals one 12 oz bottle of beer (355 mL), one 5 oz glass of wine (148 mL), or one 1½ oz glass of hard liquor (44 mL).
Lifestyle
• Do not use any products that contain nicotine or tobacco, such as cigarettes, e-cigarettes, and chewing tobacco. If you need help quitting, ask your health care provider.
◦ Do not use nicotine gum or patches before talking to your health care provider.
• Do not use illegal drugs.
• Work with your health care provider to safely reach the right body weight.
• Do physical activity if told by your health care provider. Talk to your health care provider before you begin an exercise if:
◦ You are an older adult.
◦ You have severe heart failure.
• Learn to manage stress. If you need help to do this, ask your health care provider.
• Participate in or seek rehabilitation as needed to keep or improve your independence and quality of life.
• Plan rest periods when you get tired.
Monitoring important information
• Weigh yourself every day. This will help you to notice if too much fluid is building up in your body.
◦ Weigh yourself every morning after you urinate and before you eat breakfast.
◦ Wear the same amount of clothing each time you weigh yourself.
◦ Record your daily weight. Provide your health care provider with your weight record.
• Monitor and record your pulse and blood pressure as told by your health care provider.
Dealing with extreme temperatures
• If the weather is extremely hot:
◦ Avoid vigorous physical activity.
◦ Use air conditioning or fans, or find a cooler location.
◦ Avoid caffeine and alcohol.
◦ Wear loose-fitting, lightweight, and light-colored clothing.
• If the weather is extremely cold:
◦ Avoid vigorous activity.
◦ Layer your clothes.
◦ Wear mittens or gloves, a hat, and a scarf when you go outside.
◦ Avoid alcohol.
Follow these instructions at home:
• Stay up to date with vaccines. Pneumococcal and flu (influenza) vaccines are especially important in preventing infections of the airways.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if you:
• Have a rapid weight gain.
• Have increasing shortness of breath.
• Are unable to participate in your usual physical activities.
• Get tired easily.
• Cough more than normal, especially with physical activity.
• Lose your appetite or feel nauseous.
• Have any swelling or more swelling in areas such as your hands, feet, ankles, or abdomen.
• Are unable to sleep because it is hard to breathe.
• Feel like your heart is beating quickly (palpitations).
• Become dizzy or light-headed when you stand up.
Get help right away if you:
• Have trouble breathing.
• Notice or your family notices a change in your awareness, such as having trouble staying awake or concentrating.
• Have pain or discomfort in your chest.
• Have an episode of fainting (syncope).
These symptoms may represent a serious problem that is an emergency. Do not wait to see if the symptoms will go away. Get medical help right away. Call your local emergency services (911 in the U.S.). Do not drive yourself to the hospital.
Summary
• Heart failure is a serious condition. To care for yourself, you may be asked to change your diet, take certain medicines, and make other lifestyle changes.
• Take your medicines every day. Do not stop taking them unless your health care provider tells you to do so.
• Eat heart-healthy foods, such as fresh or frozen fruits and vegetables, fish, lean meats, legumes, fat-free or low-fat dairy products, and whole-grain or high-fiber foods.
• Ask your health care provider if you have any alcohol restrictions. You may have to stop drinking alcohol if you have severe heart failure.
• Contact your health care provider if you notice problems, such as rapid weight gain or a fast heartbeat. Get help right away if you faint, or have chest pain or trouble breathing.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.

Hemodialysis, Care After
This sheet gives you information about how to care for yourself after your procedure. Your health care provider may also give you more specific instructions. If you have problems or questions, contact your health care provider.
What can I expect after the procedure?
After the procedure, it is common to have:
• Tiredness (fatigue). Energy levels usually return to normal the day after the procedure.
• Itchiness. Your health care provider may be able to prescribe medicine to relieve this.
• Achy or jittery legs. You may feel like kicking your legs. This sometimes causes sleep problems.
Follow these instructions at home:
Eating and drinking
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about eating or drinking restrictions.
• Talk with your health care provider about how much fluid you can drink. Keep track of your fluid intake so you do not drink more fluid than is allowed. This is important. Fluid can build up in your body between dialysis sessions. Built-up fluid affects your blood pressure and can make your heart work harder.
• Limit your salt (sodium) intake. This is important because:
◦ Sodium makes you thirsty. This is a problem because the amount of fluid you can drink every day is limited.
◦ Sodium affects your blood pressure levels. Controlling the amount of sodium in your diet may help you control your blood pressure levels.
• Limit your intake of the mineral potassium. Potassium levels can rise between dialysis sessions. High levels can cause a dangerous heart rhythm, which may be life-threatening.
• Limit your intake of the mineral phosphorus. Consuming too much phosphorus can cause your bones to lose calcium. This makes them weaker and more likely to break. Consuming too much phosphorus may also make your skin itch.
• Eat high-quality proteins that are low in phosphorus. High-quality proteins include those found in fish, poultry, eggs, beans, and lentils.
Care of your vascular access site
• Avoid sleeping on the site where blood is removed from your body and returned to your body (vascular access site).
• If your vascular access site is on your arm:
◦ Do not lift any heavy objects with that arm.
◦ Do not wear tight clothing over that arm.
◦ Do not have your blood pressure measured on that arm.
◦ Do not allow needle punctures on that arm, including punctures for taking blood.
• If you have a long, thin tube (catheter), do not open it between dialysis sessions.
• If you have a fistula or graft:
◦ Follow instructions from your health care provider about caring for your fistula or graft. Wash it with soap every day and before each dialysis session.
◦ Make sure you:
▪ Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds before and after you change your bandage (dressing). If soap and water are not available, use hand sanitizer.
▪ Change your dressing as told by your health care provider.
◦ Feel for a vibration over the access site (thrill) every day. A thrill means the access is working.
◦ Check your vascular access site every day for signs of infection. Check for:
▪ Redness, swelling, or pain.
▪ Fluid or blood.
▪ Warmth.
▪ Pus or a bad smell.
Activity
• Rest as told by your health care provider.
• Return to your normal activities as told by your health care provider. Ask your health care provider what activities are safe for you.
Managing constipation
Your condition may cause constipation. To prevent or treat constipation, you may need to:
• Take over-the-counter or prescription medicines.
• Eat foods that are high in fiber, such as beans, whole grains, and fresh fruits and vegetables.
• Limit foods that are high in fat and processed sugars, such as fried or sweet foods.
Alcohol use
• Do not drink alcohol if:
◦ Your health care provider tells you not to drink.
◦ You are pregnant, may be pregnant, or are planning to become pregnant.
• If you drink alcohol:
◦ Limit how much you use to:
▪ 0–1 drink a day for women.
▪ 0–2 drinks a day for men.
◦ Be aware of how much alcohol is in your drink. In the U.S., one drink equals one 12 oz bottle of beer (355 mL), one 5 oz glass of wine (148 mL), or one 1½ oz glass of hard liquor (44 mL).
General instructions
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider. This includes vitamin and mineral supplements. Talk with your health care provider before taking new supplements.
• Do not take baths, swim, or use a hot tub until your health care provider approves. Ask your health care provider if you may take showers. You may only be allowed to take sponge baths.
• Carry a wallet card, bracelet, or medical identification tag that shows you receive dialysis. Always keep the card, bracelet, or tag with you. If you are in an accident or have a medical emergency and cannot communicate, this item will let health care providers know about your condition.
• Keep all dialysis visits as told by your health care provider. Dialysis appointments should be scheduled regularly. Do not skip an appointment.
Contact a health care provider if:
• You have a fever.
• You have chills.
• Your vascular access site feels warm to the touch.
• You find a pimple on your vascular access site.
• You have redness, swelling, or pain around your vascular access site.
• You have fluid or blood coming from your vascular access site.
• You have pus or a bad smell coming from your vascular access site.
Get help right away if you:
• Have fistula or graft symptoms, such as:
◦ The hand on the side of your body that has a fistula becomes painful, numb, or very pale.
◦ Not feeling a thrill if you have a fistula or graft.
• Develop dizziness or weakness that you have not had before.
• Develop shortness of breath or chest pain.
• Have bleeding at the vascular access site that cannot be easily controlled.
• Become confused or do not know the time of day, where you are, or who you are (disoriented).
• Develop blurred vision.
• Have a seizure.
These symptoms may represent a serious problem that is an emergency. Do not wait to see if the symptoms will go away. Get medical help right away. Call your local emergency services (911 in the U.S.). Do not drive yourself to the hospital.
Summary
• After hemodialysis, it is common to have tiredness (fatigue), itchiness, and achy or jittery legs.
• Track your fluid intake, limit intake of certain minerals, eat high-quality proteins, and take vitamin and mineral supplements as told by your health care provider.
• Take proper care of your vascular access, and contact your health care provider if you have problems with your vascular access, such as warmth, redness, swelling, drainage, or bleeding at the site.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.

AV Fistula Placement, Care After
This sheet gives you information about how to care for yourself after your procedure. Your health care provider may also give you more specific instructions. If you have problems or questions, contact your health care provider.
What can I expect after the procedure?
After the procedure, it is common to:
• Feel sore.
• Feel a vibration (thrill) over the fistula.
Follow these instructions at home:
Incision care
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about how to take care of your incision. Make sure you:
◦ Wash your hands with soap and water before and after you change your bandage (dressing). If soap and water are not available, use hand sanitizer.
◦ Change your dressing as told by your health care provider.
◦ Leave stitches (sutures), skin glue, or adhesive strips in place. These skin closures may need to stay in place for 2 weeks or longer. If adhesive strip edges start to loosen and curl up, you may trim the loose edges. Do not remove adhesive strips completely unless your health care provider tells you to do that.
Fistula care
• Check your fistula site every day to make sure the thrill feels the same.
• Check your fistula site every day for signs of infection. Check for:
◦ Redness, swelling, or pain.
◦ Fluid or blood.
◦ Warmth.
◦ Pus or a bad smell.
• Raise (elevate) the affected area above the level of your heart while you are sitting or lying down.
• Do not lift anything that is heavier than 10 lb (4.5 kg), or the limit that you are told, until your health care provider says that it is safe.
• Do not lie down on your fistula arm.
• Do not let anyone draw blood or take a blood pressure reading on your fistula arm. This is important.
• Do not wear tight jewelry or clothing over your fistula arm.
Bathing
• Do not take baths, swim, or use a hot tub until your health care provider approves. Ask your health care provider if you may take showers. You may only be allowed to take sponge baths.
• Keep the area around your incision clean and dry.
Medicines
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• Ask your health care provider if any medicine prescribed to you can cause constipation. You may need to take steps to prevent or treat constipation, such as:
◦ Drink enough fluid to keep your urine pale yellow.
◦ Take over-the-counter or prescription medicines.
◦ Eat foods that are high in fiber, such as beans, whole grains, and fresh fruits and vegetables.
◦ Limit foods that are high in fat and processed sugars, such as fried or sweet foods.
General instructions
• Rest at home for a day or two.
• Return to your normal activities as told by your health care provider. Ask your health care provider what activities are safe for you.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if:
• You have redness, swelling, or pain around your fistula site.
• Your fistula site feels warm to the touch.
• You have pus or a bad smell coming from your fistula site.
• You have a fever.
• You have numbness or coldness at your fistula site.
• You feel a decrease or a change in the thrill.
Get help right away if you:
• Are bleeding from your fistula site.
• Have chest pain.
• Have trouble breathing.
Summary
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about how to take care of your incision.
• Do not let anyone draw blood or take a blood pressure reading on your fistula arm. This is important.
• Return to your normal activities as told by your health care provider. Ask your health care provider what activities are safe for you.
• Contact a health care provider if you have a change in the thrill or have any signs of infection at your fistula site.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
